column1: Linz (; German: [ˈlɪnts]; Czech: Linec) is the capital city of Upper Austria and third-largest city in Austria. It is located in the country's northern part
column2: on the Danube 30 kilometres (19 miles) south of the Czech border. In 2018
column6: with the city north of the Danube occupied by the Soviets and to the south of it by the Americans. In 2009
column7: it was a European Capital of Culture; it is a member of the UNESCO Creative Cities Network. Linz is known for its Linzer torte.

column1: Linz is in the centre of Europe
column2: lying on the Paris–Budapest west–east axis and the Malmö–Trieste north–south axis. The Danube is the main tourism and transport connection that runs through the city.Approximately 29.27% of the city's 96 km2 (37 sq mi) wide area are grassland. Further 17.95% are covered with forest. All the rest areas fall on water (6.39%)

column1: It was a provincial and local government city of the Holy Roman Empire
column2: and an important trading point connecting several routes
column3: on either side of the river Danube from the east to the west and Bohemia and Poland from north to the Balkans and Italy to the south. Being the city where the Habsburg Emperor Friedrich III spent his last years

column6: the most important city in the empire. It lost its status to Vienna and Prague after the death of the Emperor in 1493.One important inhabitant of the city was the age of discovery-era astronomer and mathematician Johannes Kepler
column7: who spent several years of his life in the city teaching mathematics. He discovered
column9: the distance-cubed-over-time-squared—or "third"—law of planetary motion. The local public university
column11: is named for him.Another noted citizen was Anton Bruckner
column12: who spent the years between 1855 and 1868 working as a local composer and organist in the Old Cathedral
column13: Linz. The Brucknerhaus is named after him.Adolf Hitler was born in Braunau am Inn (an Austrian town near the German border) and moved to Linz during his childhood. Hitler spent most of his youth in the Linz area
column15: when he left for Vienna. The family lived first in the village of Leonding on the outskirts of town
column16: and then on the Humboldtstrasse in Linz. After elementary education in Leonding
column17: Hitler was enrolled in the Realschule (secondary or high school)
column18: as was the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein. Notorious Holocaust architect Adolf Eichmann also spent his youth in Linz. Until the end of his life
column19: Hitler considered Linz to be his hometown
column20: and envisioned extensive architectural schemes for it – including a massive new Fuhrermuseum to house his collection of looted art – wanting it to become the main cultural centre of the Third Reich
column22: a city he hated.To make the city economically vibrant
column23: Hitler initiated a major industrialization of Linz shortly before
column25: the Second World War.Near the end of World War II
column26: Hitler became enamored of the musical compositions of Anton Bruckner
column29: planned to convert the monastery of St. Florian in Linz – where Bruckner had played the organ
column30: and where he was buried – into a repository of Bruckner's manuscripts.Hitler evicted the monks from the building and personally paid for the restoration of the organ and the institution of a Bruckner study center there. He also paid for the Haas collection of Bruckner's works to be published
column31: and himself purchased material for the proposed library.Additionally
column32: Hitler effected the founding of the Bruckner Symphony Orchestra
column33: which began presenting concerts in Fall 1943. His plan for one of the bell towers in Linz to play a theme from Bruckner's Fourth Symphony never came to pass. In addition to an ordnance depot
column34: Linz had a benzol (oil) plant which was bombed during the Oil Campaign on 16 October 1944. What was once the Mauthausen-Gusen concentration camp is 20 km (12 miles) east of Linz.

column1: The coat of arms of Linz developed from the seal image
column2: which was used as emblem since 1242. It showed the open city gate flanked by two crenelated towers on rocky ground. From 1288 on
column3: the gate was shown standing on water.

column1: The coat of arms shows a red plate on which stands a castle with twin towers. Those towers are crowned with three crenelations. The towers include an open door; above the door the red-white-red shield of Austria is attached.
The gate and towers symbolise the medieval fortified city. The wavy bars indicate the position of the city near the Danube. The Austrian shield is a reference to the former territorial city.

column1: Linz is one of the main economic centres of Austria. Voestalpine is a large technology and capital goods group (founded as the "Hermann-Göring-Werke" during the Second World War)
column2: which is known for the LD- ("Linz-Donawitz") procedure for the production of steel. The former "Chemie Linz" chemical group has been split up into several companies. These companies have made Linz one of Austria's most important economic centres.
due to the fact that one of the four Donau-Harbors (Donauhäfen) in Austria is located in Linz
column3: it constitutes an attractive location in regards to logistic and trading enterprises. Nonetheless manufacturing plants can – for instance - be found at the waterfront as well. The economic importance of Linz was founded over centuries in trade. Moreover
column4: the long-standing image of Linz as an industrial city was a result of the National Socialism. As a result of this large industrial enterprises are still located in Linz nowadays. Important examples are the Voestalpine AG or "Chemie Linz" – as already mentioned above. From an economical perspective they represent a large number of jobs and of course industry related enterprises.
